flowRoot.flowPara: - a powerful new account of multi-agent knowledgein the situation calculus
- by explicitly reifying observations made by each agent as the world evolves
- utlising new regression techniques to provide an effective reasoning procedure
K(agt,s',s) identifies situations that the agent considers possible
Knows(agt,ϕ,s) if ϕ holds in all situations considered possible
Situations considered possible after an action are successors of those considered possible before the action
What is known after an action is thus determined by what was known before the action
Since the effects of each action are known, one can answer knowledge queries using the regression operator
- inherits solution to the frame problem
- all agents must be aware of all actions
- reasoning requires a full situation term
- so agents cannot reason about their own knowledge
Each agent will make a (possibly empty) set of observations whenever a set of concurrent actions is performed:
An agent's knowledge must depend only on its local history of observations:
What each agent observes can be flexibly axiomatized as needed. For example, agents may observe all actions that they themselves perform:
Some actions may be completely unobservable by an agent, meaning its obs.
- agents consider possible all sequences of actions that would be completely unobservable to them
- our new Property Persistence operator permits effective reasoning about all future situations
- thus we maintain the representational and computational elegance of the standard approach
- while significantly increasing its expressive power
Knowledge can be defined relative to an ObsHist rather than a situation
Agents must consider all sequences of actions that would be completely unobservable to them
Property Persistence operator can be used to decide whether ϕ holds in all unobservable situations
Regression can then be used to answer the knowledge query as before
Knows(agt,ϕ,o∙h) can be answered using only o and h, rather than a full situation term.
We create a robustly multi-agent formalism by distinguishing between what occurs in the world and what is observed by each agent
